sn6.11:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā rājagahe viharati sappinītīre.
sn6.11:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, on the bank of the Serpentine river.
sn6.11:1.2.comm: The Serpentine (sappinī) is probably the modern Panchane (from pañcānana, “five-mouthed”). There was a wanderer’s hermitage on its banks (AN 3.64, AN 4.30, AN 4.185).

sn6.11:1.3.pli: Atha kho brahmā sanaṅkumāro abhikkantāya rattiyā abhikkantavaṇṇo kevalakappaṃ sappinītīraṃ obhāsetvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi.
sn6.11:1.3.eng: Then, late at night, the glorious divinity Sanaṅkumāra, lighting up the entire Serpentine riverbank, went up to the Buddha, bowed, stood to one side,
sn6.11:1.3.comm: Sanaṅkumāra (“Everyoung”) became a Hindu deity closely associated with the worship of Krishna. He first appears in the seventh chapter of the Chāndogya Upaniṣad. He speaks this verse also at DN 3:1.28.2, DN 27:32.2, MN 53:25.3, AN 11.10:6.1, and it was endorsed by the Buddha. He features in two extended discussions among the gods, his appearance heralded by a great light in the north (DN 18:15.1, DN 19:15.1). He also appears in DN 20:20.3.

sn6.11:1.4.pli: Ekamantaṃ ṭhito kho brahmā sanaṅkumāro bhagavato santike imaṃ gāthaṃ abhāsi:
sn6.11:1.4.eng: and spoke this verse in the Buddha’s presence:

sn6.11:2.2.eng: who take clan as the standard.

sn6.11:2.3.eng: But one accomplished in knowledge and conduct

sn6.11:2.4.eng: is best among gods and humans.”

sn6.11:3.1.eng: That’s what the divinity Sanaṅkumāra said,

sn6.11:3.3.pli: Atha kho brahmā sanaṅkumāro “samanuñño me satthā”ti bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā tatthevantaradhāyīti.
sn6.11:3.3.eng: Then the divinity Sanaṅkumāra, knowing that the teacher approved, bowed and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right, before vanishing right there.

sn6.12:1.1.comm: Also at AN 4.68, the verse is spoken by the Buddha with additional explanation at SN 17.35 = Kd 17:2.5.12.

sn6.12:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā rājagahe viharati gijjhakūṭe pabbate acirapakkante devadatte.
sn6.12:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, on the Vulture’s Peak Mountain, not long after Devadatta had left.

sn6.12:1.3.pli: Atha kho brahmā sahampati abhikkantāya rattiyā abhikkantavaṇṇo kevalakappaṃ gijjhakūṭaṃ pabbataṃ obhāsetvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi.
sn6.12:1.3.eng: Then, late at night, the glorious divinity Sahampati, lighting up the entire Vulture’s Peak, went up to the Buddha, bowed, stood to one side,

sn6.12:1.4.pli: Ekamantaṃ ṭhito kho brahmā sahampati devadattaṃ ārabbha bhagavato santike imaṃ gāthaṃ abhāsi:
sn6.12:1.4.eng: and spoke this verse in the Buddha’s presence:

sn6.12:2.1.eng: “The banana plant is destroyed by its own fruit,

sn6.12:2.2.eng: as are the bamboo and the reed.

sn6.13:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā māgadhesu viharati andhakavinde.
sn6.13:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Magadhans at Andhakavinda.
sn6.13:1.1.comm: The Buddha taught Ānanda there (AN 5.114). It lay to the west of Rājagaha on the road from Varanasi. Once, arriving there from Varanasi, the Buddha allowed porridge (Kd 6:24.1.1, cf. AN 5.207). At Kd 2:12.1.1, Mahākassapa was swept away in a river while returning from Andhakavinda. That river is identified by the commentary as the Serpentine, but that is usually said to be the Panchane, which lies to the east of Rājagaha. Perhaps the river near Andhakavinda was, rather, the Paimar, which lies about three hours walk to the west of Rājagaha.

sn6.13:1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhagavā rattandhakāratimisāyaṃ abbhokāse nisinno hoti, devo ca ekamekaṃ phusāyati.
sn6.13:1.2.eng: Now at that time the Buddha was meditating in the open during the dark of night, while a gentle rain drizzled down.

sn6.13:1.3.pli: Atha kho brahmā sahampati abhikkantāya rattiyā abhikkantavaṇṇo kevalakappaṃ andhakavindaṃ obhāsetvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi.
sn6.13:1.3.eng: Then, late at night, the glorious divinity Sahampati, lighting up the entirety of Andhakavinda, went up to the Buddha, bowed, stood to one side,

sn6.13:1.4.pli: Ekamantaṃ ṭhito kho brahmā sahampati bhagavato santike imā gāthāyo abhāsi:
sn6.13:1.4.eng: and recited these verses in the Buddha’s presence:

sn6.13:2.1.comm: This verse was spoken by Mahācunda at Thag 2.11:2.1.

sn6.13:2.2.eng: and practice to be released from fetters.

sn6.13:2.3.eng: If you don’t find enjoyment there,

sn6.13:2.4.eng: live in the Saṅgha, self-protected and mindful.

sn6.13:3.1.eng: Walking for alms from family to family,

sn6.13:3.2.eng: with senses guarded, alert and mindful.

sn6.13:3.4.eng: free of fear, freed in the fearless.

sn6.13:4.2.eng: where the lightning flashes and the heavens thunder

sn6.13:4.3.eng: in the dark of the night;

sn6.13:4.4.eng: there meditates a mendicant, free of goosebumps.

sn6.13:5.1.eng: For this is ever seen by me,

sn6.13:5.2.eng: it isn’t just the testament of hearsay.

sn6.13:5.4.eng: there are a thousand conquerors of Death.
sn6.13:5.4.comm: Maccuhāyi is glossed by the commentaries as either “abandoner” (maccuhāyinanti maraṇapariccāginaṁ) or “conqueror” (maraṇābhibhū maccuhāyī). The phrase seems to be used in martial contexts where it carries a similar force to jetvā māraṁ just below.

sn6.13:6.1.eng: And of trainees, more than five hundred,
sn6.13:6.1.comm: “More than five hundred” is the count of stream-enterers also at SN 55.10:3.3 = DN 18:1.7 = DN 16:2.7.15; see too MN 73:7.3 ff. and MN 76:53.2.

sn6.13:6.2.comm: The ca here indicates the numbers should be added, totaling 1,500.

sn6.13:6.4.eng: freed from rebirth in the animal realm.

sn6.13:7.1.eng: And as for the rest of folk

sn6.13:7.2.eng: who I think have shared in merit—

sn6.14:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī.

sn6.14:2.1.eng: “Once upon a time, mendicants, there was a king named Aruṇavā.
sn6.14:2.1.comm: At DN 14:1.12.4 he is called Aruṇa.

sn6.14:2.2.pli: Rañño kho pana, bhikkhave, aruṇavato aruṇavatī nāma rājadhānī ahosi.
sn6.14:2.2.eng: He had a capital named Aruṇavatī.

sn6.14:2.3.pli: Aruṇavatiṃ kho pana, bhikkhave, rājadhāniṃ sikhī bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho upanissāya vihāsi.
sn6.14:2.3.eng: Sikhī the Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha lived supported by Aruṇavatī.
sn6.14:2.3.comm: Sikhī means “halo” or “crown”. DN 14:1.12.4 says Aruṇa was his father, and Pabhāvatī his mother. The son of King Dawn and Queen Radiant in the City of the Dawn, Sikhī is the streaming rays of sunrise. These names recall a solar myth.

sn6.14:2.4.pli: Sikhissa kho pana, bhikkhave, bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa abhibhūsambhavaṃ nāma sāvakayugaṃ ahosi aggaṃ bhaddayugaṃ.
sn6.14:2.4.eng: Sikhī had a fine pair of chief disciples named Abhibhū and Sambhava.
sn6.14:2.4.comm: Abhibhū (“Victor”) and Sambhava (“son of Śambhu the blessed”) are also at DN 14:1.9.2. Śambhu is commonly found in the Rig Veda in the sense, “blessing, benefit”, and became a common name or epithet of gods, etc.

sn6.14:2.5.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, sikhī bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho abhibhuṃ bhikkhuṃ āmantesi:
sn6.14:2.5.eng: Then the Buddha Sikhī addressed the mendicant Abhibhū,

sn6.14:2.6.pli: ‘āyāma, brāhmaṇa, yena aññataro brahmaloko tenupasaṅkamissāma, yāva bhattassa kālo bhavissatī’ti.
sn6.14:2.6.eng: ‘Come, brahmin, let’s go to one of the realms of divinity until it’s time for our meal.’
sn6.14:2.6.comm: Gotama occasionally addresses a mendicant as brahmin, but only by way of special encouragement (eg. MN 86:17.6).

sn6.14:2.7.pli: ‘Evaṃ, bhante’ti kho bhikkhave, abhibhū bhikkhu sikhissa bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa paccassosi.

sn6.14:2.8.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, sikhī bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho abhibhū ca bhikkhu—seyyathāpi nāma balavā puriso samiñjitaṃ vā bāhaṃ pasāreyya, pasāritaṃ vā bāhaṃ samiñjeyya; evameva—aruṇavatiyā rājadhāniyā antarahitā tasmiṃ brahmaloke pāturahesuṃ.
sn6.14:2.8.eng: Then, as easily as a strong person would extend or contract their arm, they vanished from Aruṇavatī and appeared in that realm of divinity.

sn6.14:3.1.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, sikhī bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho abhibhuṃ bhikkhuṃ āmantesi:
sn6.14:3.1.eng: Then the Buddha Sikhī addressed the mendicant Abhibhū,

sn6.14:3.2.pli: ‘paṭibhātu, brāhmaṇa, taṃ brahmuno ca brahmaparisāya ca brahmapārisajjānañca dhammī kathā’ti.
sn6.14:3.2.eng: ‘Brahmin, teach the Dhamma as you feel inspired for that Divinity, his assembly, and the members of his retinue.’

sn6.14:3.3.pli: ‘Evaṃ, bhante’ti kho, bhikkhave, abhibhū bhikkhu sikhissa bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa paṭissutvā, brahmānañca brahmaparisañca brahmapārisajje ca dhammiyā kathāya sandassesi samādapesi samuttejesi sampahaṃsesi.
sn6.14:3.3.eng: ‘Yes, sir,’ replied Abhibhū. Then he educated, encouraged, fired up, and inspired them with a Dhamma talk.

sn6.14:3.4.pli: Tatra sudaṃ, bhikkhave, brahmā ca brahmaparisā ca brahmapārisajjā ca ujjhāyanti khiyyanti vipācenti:
sn6.14:3.4.eng: But the Divinity, his assembly, and his retinue complained, grumbled, and objected,

sn6.14:3.5.pli: ‘acchariyaṃ vata, bho, abbhutaṃ vata bho, kathañhi nāma satthari sammukhībhūte sāvako dhammaṃ desessatī’ti.
sn6.14:3.5.eng: ‘Oh lord, how incredible, how amazing! How on earth can a disciple teach Dhamma in the presence of the Teacher?’

sn6.14:4.1.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, sikhī bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho abhibhuṃ bhikkhuṃ āmantesi:
sn6.14:4.1.eng: Then the Buddha Sikhī addressed the mendicant Abhibhū,

sn6.14:4.2.pli: ‘ujjhāyanti kho te, brāhmaṇa, brahmā ca brahmaparisā ca brahmapārisajjā ca—
sn6.14:4.2.eng: ‘Brahmin, the Divinity, his assembly, and his retinue are complaining

sn6.14:4.3.pli: acchariyaṃ vata bho, abbhutaṃ vata bho, kathañhi nāma satthari sammukhībhūte sāvako dhammaṃ desessatīti.
sn6.14:4.3.eng: that a disciple teaches Dhamma in the presence of the Teacher.

sn6.14:4.4.pli: Tena hi tvaṃ, brāhmaṇa, bhiyyoso mattāya brahmānañca brahmaparisañca brahmapārisajje ca saṃvejehī’ti.
sn6.14:4.4.eng: Well then, brahmin, stir them up even more!’
sn6.14:4.4.comm: The Buddha understood that you do not have to always give the audience what they want.

sn6.14:4.5.pli: ‘Evaṃ, bhante’ti kho, bhikkhave, abhibhū bhikkhu sikhissa bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa paṭissutvā dissamānenapi kāyena dhammaṃ desesi, adissamānenapi kāyena dhammaṃ desesi, dissamānenapi heṭṭhimena upaḍḍhakāyena adissamānena uparimena upaḍḍhakāyena dhammaṃ desesi, dissamānenapi uparimena upaḍḍhakāyena adissamānena heṭṭhimena upaḍḍhakāyena dhammaṃ desesi.
sn6.14:4.5.eng: ‘Yes, sir,’ replied Abhibhū. Then he taught Dhamma with his body visible; with his body invisible; with the lower half visible and the upper half invisible; and with the upper half visible and the lower half invisible.
sn6.14:4.5.comm: This display is unique in the Suttas. It is referred to at Ps 3.2:15.2, which calls it “the power of transformation” (vikubbanā iddhi), for which see DN 18:22.3 and Thag 20.1:44.3.

sn6.14:4.6.pli: Tatra sudaṃ, bhikkhave, brahmā ca brahmaparisā ca brahmapārisajjā ca acchariyabbhutacittajātā ahesuṃ:
sn6.14:4.6.eng: And the Divinity, his assembly, and his retinue, their minds full of wonder and amazement, thought,

sn6.14:4.7.pli: ‘acchariyaṃ vata bho, abbhutaṃ vata bho, samaṇassa mahiddhikatā mahānubhāvatā’ti.
sn6.14:4.7.eng: ‘Oh lord, how incredible, how amazing! The ascetic has such psychic power and might!’

sn6.14:5.1.pli: Atha kho abhibhū bhikkhu sikhiṃ bhagavantaṃ arahantaṃ sammāsambuddhaṃ etadavoca:
sn6.14:5.1.eng: Then Abhibhū said to the Buddha Sikhī,

sn6.14:5.2.pli: ‘abhijānāmi khvāhaṃ, bhante, bhikkhusaṅghassa majjhe evarūpiṃ vācaṃ bhāsitā—
sn6.14:5.2.eng: ‘Sir, I recall having said this in the middle of the Saṅgha:

sn6.14:5.3.pli: pahomi khvāhaṃ, āvuso, brahmaloke ṭhito sahassilokadhātuṃ sarena viññāpetun’ti.
sn6.14:5.3.eng: “Standing in the realm of divinity, I can make my voice heard throughout the thousandfold galaxy.”’
sn6.14:5.3.comm: Ānanda asks the Buddha about this at AN 3.80.

sn6.14:5.4.eng: ‘Now is the time, brahmin! Now is the time, brahmin!

sn6.14:5.5.pli: yaṃ tvaṃ, brāhmaṇa, brahmaloke ṭhito sahassilokadhātuṃ sarena viññāpeyyāsī’ti.
sn6.14:5.5.eng: Standing in the realm of divinity, make your voice heard throughout the thousandfold galaxy.’

sn6.14:5.6.pli: ‘Evaṃ, bhante’ti kho, bhikkhave, abhibhū bhikkhu sikhissa bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa paṭissutvā brahmaloke ṭhito imā gāthāyo abhāsi:
sn6.14:5.6.eng: ‘Yes, sir,’ replied Abhibhū. Standing in the realm of divinity, he spoke this verse:

sn6.14:6.1.comm: These verses are spoken by the otherwise unknown monk Abhibhūta at Thag 3.13. Perhaps there has been some confusion in the name.

sn6.14:6.2.eng: Devote yourselves to the teachings of the Buddha!

sn6.14:6.4.eng: as an elephant a hut of reeds.

sn6.14:7.4.eng: will make an end of suffering.’

sn6.14:8.1.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, sikhī ca bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho abhibhū ca bhikkhu brahmānañca brahmaparisañca brahmapārisajje ca saṃvejetvā—
sn6.14:8.1.eng: Having inspired that Divinity, his assembly, and his retinue with a sense of awe,

sn6.14:8.2.pli: seyyathāpi nāma …pe… tasmiṃ brahmaloke antarahitā aruṇavatiyā rājadhāniyā pāturahesuṃ.
sn6.14:8.2.eng: as easily as a strong person would extend or contract their arm, Sikhī and Abhibhū vanished from that realm of divinity and appeared in Aruṇavatī.

sn6.14:8.3.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, sikhī bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho bhikkhū āmantesi:
sn6.14:8.3.eng: Then the Buddha Sikhī addressed the mendicants,

sn6.14:8.4.pli: ‘assuttha no tumhe, bhikkhave, abhibhussa bhikkhuno brahmaloke ṭhitassa gāthāyo bhāsamānassā’ti?
sn6.14:8.4.eng: ‘Mendicants, did you hear the mendicant Abhibhū speaking a verse while standing in a realm of divinity?’

sn6.14:8.5.pli: ‘Assumha kho mayaṃ, bhante, abhibhussa bhikkhuno brahmaloke ṭhitassa gāthāyo bhāsamānassā’ti.

sn6.14:8.6.pli: ‘Yathā kathaṃ pana tumhe, bhikkhave, assuttha abhibhussa bhikkhuno brahmaloke ṭhitassa gāthāyo bhāsamānassā’ti?

sn6.14:8.7.pli: Evaṃ kho mayaṃ, bhante, assumha abhibhussa bhikkhuno brahmaloke ṭhitassa gāthāyo bhāsamānassa:

sn6.14:9.2.eng: Devote yourselves to the teachings of the Buddha!

sn6.14:9.4.eng: as an elephant a hut of reeds.

sn6.14:10.4.eng: will make an end of suffering.”

sn6.14:11.1.pli: ‘Evaṃ kho mayaṃ, bhante, assumha abhibhussa bhikkhuno brahmaloke ṭhitassa gāthāyo bhāsamānassā’ti.

sn6.14:11.3.pli: sādhu kho tumhe, bhikkhave, assuttha abhibhussa bhikkhuno brahmaloke ṭhitassa gāthāyo bhāsamānassā’”ti.
sn6.14:11.3.eng: It’s good that you heard the mendicant Abhibhū speaking this verse while standing in a realm of divinity.’”

sn6.14:12.1.pli: Idamavoca bhagavā, attamanā te bhikkhū bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinandunti.
sn6.14:12.1.eng: That is what the Buddha said. Satisfied, the mendicants approved what the Buddha said.

sn6.15:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā kusinārāyaṃ viharati upavattane mallānaṃ sālavane antarena yamakasālānaṃ parinibbānasamaye.
sn6.15:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying between a pair of sal trees in the sal forest of the Mallas at Upavattana near Kusinārā at the time of his full extinguishment.
sn6.15:1.1.comm: This is an excerpt from the Mahāparinibbānasutta, picking up at DN 16:6.7.1.

sn6.15:1.2.eng: Then the Buddha said to the mendicants:

sn6.15:1.3.eng: “Come now, mendicants, I say to you all:

sn6.15:1.4.comm: This is perhaps the briefest summary possible of the Buddha’s teaching. The world as it is, and all the beings in it, are created and sustained through conditions. Since the conditions that sustain them are finite, the conditioned phenomena are also finite and must come to an end. Reflecting on this gives rise to gratitude for the life we have and the opportunities it grants us, and determination to live and practice dedicated to the realization of the unconditioned, Nibbana.

sn6.15:1.5.eng: These were the Realized One’s last words.
sn6.15:1.5.comm: The commentary says this line was added at the Council.

sn6.15:2.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ samāpajji. Paṭhamā jhānā vuṭṭhahitvā dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ samāpajji. Dutiyā jhānā vuṭṭhahitvā tatiyaṃ jhānaṃ samāpajji. Tatiyā jhānā vuṭṭhahitvā catutthaṃ jhānaṃ samāpajji. Catutthā jhānā vuṭṭhahitvā ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ samāpajji. Ākāsānañcāyatanā vuṭṭhahitvā viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ samāpajji. Viññāṇañcāyatanā vuṭṭhahitvā ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ samāpajji. Ākiñcaññāyatanā vuṭṭhahitvā nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ samāpajji. Nevasaññānāsaññāyatanā vuṭṭhahitvā saññāvedayitanirodhaṃ samāpajji.
sn6.15:2.1.eng: Then the Buddha entered the first absorption. Emerging from that, he entered the second absorption. Emerging from that, he successively entered into and emerged from the third absorption, the fourth absorption, the dimension of infinite space, the dimension of infinite consciousness, the dimension of nothingness, and the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception. Then he entered the cessation of perception and feeling.
sn6.15:2.1.comm: Even on his deathbed, the Buddha retains mastery over his mind.| At this point in DN 16:6.8.2, Ānanda and Anuruddha discuss whether the Buddha is dead.

sn6.15:3.1.pli: Saññāvedayitanirodhā vuṭṭhahitvā nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ samāpajji. Nevasaññānāsaññāyatanā vuṭṭhahitvā ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ samāpajji. Ākiñcaññāyatanā vuṭṭhahitvā viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ samāpajji. Viññāṇañcāyatanā vuṭṭhahitvā ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ samāpajji. Ākāsānañcāyatanā vuṭṭhahitvā catutthaṃ jhānaṃ samāpajji. Catutthā jhānā vuṭṭhahitvā tatiyaṃ jhānaṃ samāpajji. Tatiyā jhānā vuṭṭhahitvā dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ samāpajji. Dutiyā jhānā vuṭṭhahitvā paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ samāpajji. Paṭhamā jhānā vuṭṭhahitvā dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ samāpajji. Dutiyā jhānā vuṭṭhahitvā tatiyaṃ jhānaṃ samāpajji. Tatiyā jhānā vuṭṭhahitvā catutthaṃ jhānaṃ samāpajji. Catutthā jhānā vuṭṭhahitvā samanantaraṃ bhagavā parinibbāyi.
sn6.15:3.1.eng: Then he emerged from the cessation of perception and feeling and entered the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception. Emerging from that, he successively entered into and emerged from the dimension of nothingness, the dimension of infinite consciousness, the dimension of infinite space, the fourth absorption, the third absorption, the second absorption, and the first absorption. Emerging from that, he successively entered into and emerged from the second absorption and the third absorption. Then he entered the fourth absorption. Emerging from that the Buddha immediately became fully extinguished.

sn6.15:3.2.pli: Parinibbute bhagavati saha parinibbānā brahmā sahampati imaṃ gāthaṃ abhāsi:
sn6.15:3.2.eng: When the Buddha was fully quenched, along with the full extinguishment, the divinity Sahampati spoke this verse:

sn6.15:4.1.comm: Each of these characters reveal something of themselves in their verses. Sahampati, as a royal deity, emphasizes the universal nature of the teaching and the grandeur of the Buddha.

sn6.15:4.2.eng: must lay down this bag of bones.
sn6.15:4.2.comm: “Bag of bones” is a loose rendering of samussaya.

sn6.15:4.3.eng: For even a Teacher such as this,

sn6.15:4.5.eng: the Realized One, attained to power,
sn6.15:4.5.comm: The ten powers of a Realized One are detailed at AN 10.21 and MN 12:9.1.

sn6.15:5.1.pli: Parinibbute bhagavati saha parinibbānā sakko devānamindo imaṃ gāthaṃ abhāsi:
sn6.15:5.1.eng: When the Buddha was fully quenched, Sakka, lord of gods, spoke this verse:

sn6.15:6.1.comm: Less creative than Brahmā, Sakka repeats a famous verse spoken by the Buddha at SN 15.20:8.1 and DN 17:2.17.5.

sn6.15:6.2.eng: their nature is to rise and fall;

sn6.15:7.1.pli: Parinibbute bhagavati saha parinibbānā āyasmā ānando imaṃ gāthaṃ abhāsi:
sn6.15:7.1.eng: When the Buddha was fully quenched, Venerable Ānanda spoke this verse:
sn6.15:7.1.comm: This verse follows Anuruddha’s in DN 16.

sn6.15:8.3.eng: When the Buddha, endowed with all fine qualities,

sn6.15:9.1.pli: Parinibbute bhagavati saha parinibbānā āyasmā anuruddho imā gāthāyo abhāsi:
sn6.15:9.1.eng: When the Buddha was fully quenched, Venerable Anuruddha spoke this verse:

sn6.15:10.1.comm: Anuruddha was a reclusive meditator who specialized in mindfulness of breathing. Here he remarks on the fact that, since breathing ceases in the fourth absorption (SN 36.11:2.19), the Buddha’s breathing had already stopped before he died.

sn6.15:10.2.eng: for the unaffected one of steady heart.

sn6.15:10.4.eng: the Clear-eyed One was fully quenched.

sn6.15:11.1.eng: He put up with painful feelings

sn6.15:11.4.eng: was like the extinguishing of a lamp.”

sn6.15:12.5.eng: The Linked Discourses on the Divinity are complete.

sn6.2:1.1.comm: The Buddha relates this event at AN 4.21.

sn6.2:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā uruvelāyaṃ viharati najjā nerañjarāya tīre ajapālanigrodhamūle paṭhamābhisambuddho.
sn6.2:1.2.eng: At one time, when he was first awakened, the Buddha was staying in Uruvelā at the root of the goatherd’s banyan tree on the bank of the Nerañjarā River.

sn6.2:1.3.pli: Atha kho bhagavato rahogatassa paṭisallīnassa evaṃ cetaso parivitakko udapādi:
sn6.2:1.3.eng: Then as he was in private retreat this thought came to his mind,

sn6.2:1.4.pli: “dukkhaṃ kho agāravo viharati appatisso, kaṃ nu khvāhaṃ samaṇaṃ vā brāhmaṇaṃ vā sakkatvā garuṃ katvā upanissāya vihareyyan”ti?
sn6.2:1.4.eng: “One without respect and reverence lives in suffering. What ascetic or brahmin should I honor and respect and rely on?”

sn6.2:2.2.pli: “aparipuṇṇassa kho sīlakkhandhassa pāripūriyā aññaṃ samaṇaṃ vā brāhmaṇaṃ vā sakkatvā garuṃ katvā upanissāya vihareyyaṃ.
sn6.2:2.2.eng: “I’d honor and respect and rely on another ascetic or brahmin so as to complete the entire spectrum of ethics, if it were incomplete.

sn6.2:2.3.pli: Na kho panāhaṃ passāmi sadevake loke samārake sabrahmake sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiyā pajāya sadevamanussāya attanā sīlasampannataraṃ aññaṃ samaṇaṃ vā brāhmaṇaṃ vā, yamahaṃ sakkatvā garuṃ katvā upanissāya vihareyyaṃ.
sn6.2:2.3.eng: But I don’t see any other ascetic or brahmin in this world—with its gods, Māras, and Divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans—who is more accomplished than myself in ethics, who I should honor and respect and rely on.

sn6.2:3.1.pli: Aparipuṇṇassa kho samādhikkhandhassa pāripūriyā aññaṃ samaṇaṃ vā brāhmaṇaṃ vā sakkatvā garuṃ katvā upanissāya vihareyyaṃ.
sn6.2:3.1.eng: I’d honor and respect and rely on another ascetic or brahmin so as to complete the entire spectrum of immersion, if it were incomplete.

sn6.2:3.2.pli: Na kho panāhaṃ passāmi sadevake loke …pe… attanā samādhisampannataraṃ aññaṃ samaṇaṃ vā brāhmaṇaṃ vā, yamahaṃ sakkatvā garuṃ katvā upanissāya vihareyyaṃ.
sn6.2:3.2.eng: But I don’t see any other ascetic or brahmin … who is more accomplished than myself in immersion …

sn6.2:4.1.pli: Aparipuṇṇassa paññākkhandhassa pāripūriyā aññaṃ samaṇaṃ vā brāhmaṇaṃ vā sakkatvā garuṃ katvā upanissāya vihareyyaṃ.
sn6.2:4.1.eng: I’d honor and respect and rely on another ascetic or brahmin so as to complete the entire spectrum of wisdom, if it were incomplete.

sn6.2:4.2.pli: Na kho panāhaṃ passāmi sadevake …pe… attanā paññāsampannataraṃ aññaṃ samaṇaṃ vā brāhmaṇaṃ vā, yamahaṃ sakkatvā garuṃ katvā upanissāya vihareyyaṃ.
sn6.2:4.2.eng: But I don’t see any other ascetic or brahmin … who is more accomplished than myself in wisdom …

sn6.2:5.1.pli: Aparipuṇṇassa kho vimuttikkhandhassa pāripūriyā aññaṃ samaṇaṃ vā brāhmaṇaṃ vā sakkatvā garuṃ katvā upanissāya vihareyyaṃ.
sn6.2:5.1.eng: I’d honor and respect and rely on another ascetic or brahmin so as to complete the entire spectrum of freedom, if it were incomplete.

sn6.2:5.2.pli: Na kho panāhaṃ passāmi sadevake …pe… attanā vimuttisampannataraṃ aññaṃ samaṇaṃ vā brāhmaṇaṃ vā, yamahaṃ sakkatvā garuṃ katvā upanissāya vihareyyaṃ.
sn6.2:5.2.eng: But I don’t see any other ascetic or brahmin … who is more accomplished than myself in freedom …

sn6.2:6.1.pli: Aparipuṇṇassa kho vimuttiñāṇadassanakkhandhassa pāripūriyā aññaṃ samaṇaṃ vā brāhmaṇaṃ vā sakkatvā garuṃ katvā upanissāya vihareyyaṃ.
sn6.2:6.1.eng: I’d honor and respect and rely on another ascetic or brahmin so as to complete the entire spectrum of the knowledge and vision of freedom, if it were incomplete.

sn6.2:6.2.pli: Na kho panāhaṃ passāmi sadevake loke samārake sabrahmake sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiyā pajāya sadevamanussāya attanā vimuttiñāṇadassanasampannataraṃ aññaṃ samaṇaṃ vā brāhmaṇaṃ vā, yamahaṃ sakkatvā garuṃ katvā upanissāya vihareyyaṃ.
sn6.2:6.2.eng: But I don’t see any other ascetic or brahmin in this world—with its gods, Māras, and Divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans—who is more accomplished than myself in the knowledge and vision of freedom, who I should honor and respect and rely on.

sn6.2:6.3.pli: Yannūnāhaṃ yvāyaṃ dhammo mayā abhisambuddho tameva dhammaṃ sakkatvā garuṃ katvā upanissāya vihareyyan”ti.
sn6.2:6.3.eng: Why don’t I honor and respect and rely on the same Dhamma to which I was awakened?”

sn6.2:7.1.pli: Atha kho brahmā sahampati bhagavato cetasā cetoparivitakkamaññāya—seyyathāpi nāma balavā puriso samiñjitaṃ vā bāhaṃ pasāreyya pasāritaṃ vā bāhaṃ samiñjeyya; evameva—brahmaloke antarahito bhagavato purato pāturahosi.
sn6.2:7.1.eng: Then the divinity Sahampati knew what the Buddha was thinking. As easily as a strong person would extend or contract their arm, he vanished from the realm of divinity and reappeared in front of the Buddha.

sn6.2:7.2.pli: Atha kho brahmā sahampati ekaṃsaṃ uttarāsaṅgaṃ karitvā yena bhagavā tenañjaliṃ paṇāmetvā bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn6.2:7.2.eng: He arranged his robe over one shoulder, raised his joined palms toward the Buddha, and said:

sn6.2:7.3.eng: “That’s so true, Blessed One! That’s so true, Holy One!

sn6.2:7.4.pli: Yepi te, bhante, ahesuṃ atītamaddhānaṃ arahanto sammāsambuddhā, tepi bhagavanto dhammaññeva sakkatvā garuṃ katvā upanissāya vihariṃsu;
sn6.2:7.4.eng: All the perfected ones, the fully awakened Buddhas who lived in the past honored and respected and relied on this same teaching.

sn6.2:7.5.pli: yepi te, bhante, bhavissanti anāgatamaddhānaṃ arahanto sammāsambuddhā tepi bhagavanto dhammaññeva sakkatvā garuṃ katvā upanissāya viharissanti.
sn6.2:7.5.eng: All the perfected ones, the fully awakened Buddhas who will live in the future will honor and respect and rely on this same teaching.

sn6.2:7.6.pli: Bhagavāpi, bhante, etarahi arahaṃ sammāsambuddho dhammaññeva sakkatvā garuṃ katvā upanissāya viharatū”ti.
sn6.2:7.6.eng: May the Blessed One, who is the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha at present, also honor and respect and rely on this same teaching.”

sn6.2:7.7.pli: Idamavoca brahmā sahampati, idaṃ vatvā athāparaṃ etadavoca:
sn6.2:7.7.eng: This is what the divinity Sahampati said. Then he went on to say:

sn6.2:8.4.eng: destroyer of the sorrows of many—

sn6.2:9.2.eng: they did live, they do live,

sn6.2:9.4.eng: This is the nature of the Buddhas.

sn6.2:10.1.comm: For attakāma (“desires self-knowledge”) see MN 31:3.5.

sn6.2:10.2.comm: These lines always appear in a Brahmanical context (AN 4.21:11.1, AN 7.62:12.1), and it seems the Buddha is playing with two senses of mahatta. Normally it means “greatness” but it can also stand for the Sanskrit mahātman, “great Self”. Read in that way the two phrases attakāma and mahattamabhikaṅkhatā would both mean “desiring the True Self” in the Upaniṣadic system. For the Buddha, they meant perfecting oneself through development.

sn6.2:10.4.eng: remembering the instructions of the Buddhas.”
